author: jhoneill
body:
# Steps to reproduce (this is not specific to the package management module and appears to apply  widely. 

```powershell
Get-Module -ListAvailable PackageManagement | select -expand path

Import-module packageManagement 

(get-module PackageManagement).path
```

# Expected behavior

```none
The two get-module commands should output the same path.  
```

# Actual behavior

```none
When the module is loaded, the path returned appears to become the path the root module listed in the manifest. 
So in this example it returns PackageManagement.psM1 not \PackageManagement.psD1

However if this path is used to load a module in a new or later session loading the psM file won't load all the components needed for successful use of the module. (e.g. format files, type files, assembly files) - in this case loading the PSM1 result in 22 fewer items returned by get-formatData

This primarily affects testing scenarios . 
```

# Environment data
```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.0-preview.6
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.0-preview.6
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.18362
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

```
Note this does not appear to be a new issue, it seems to happen in all versions of PowerShell.

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body:
Yeah, I'm seeing the same thing from that repro. 

That definitely doesn't seem right. Kind of surprising this hasn't been raised before. 😬

comments.author: gwojan
comments.body: This actually repros on `Windows PowerShell 5.1` as well.

title: Wrong path returned by get module / (get-command).module
